DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF KOREAN MINISTERS AND OFFICIALS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move :

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate-
(1) expresses its profound sympathy at the loss of the lives of Ministers and officials of the Government of the Republic of Korea in the bomb explosion in Rangoon, Burma on Sunday 9 October;
(2) reaffirms its abhorrence of and opposition to terrorism;

(3) reaffirms its support for the people of the Republic of Korea and calls on all nations with interests and concerns in the Korean Peninsula to exercise restraint and moderation at this difficult time; and
(4) requests the President to convey the terms of this resolution to the Speaker of the National Assembly of the Republic of Korea.

Mr President, last Saturday, 8 October, President Chun Doo Hwan of the Republic of Korea set out from Seoul to visit Burma, Sri Lanka, Australia, New Zealand and Brunei. He was to arrive, together with a substantial entourage, in Perth next Sunday, 16 October. He was to come to Canberra on 17 October and hold discussions with us on 18 October before visiting Sydney on 19 October and departing for New Zealand on 20 October. As a result of tragic circumstances, that visit has been postponed to another time.

The members of the Korean official party who were killed in the bomb explosion included the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of the Economic Planning Board, the Minister of Foreign Affairs, the Minister of Commerce and Industry, the Minister of Energy and Resources, the Secretary-General to the President of the ruling Democratic Justice Party, the Vice-Minister of Agriculture and Fisheries, the Senior Secretary to the President for Economic Affairs and the Co-ordinator of the Overseas Co-operation Council. Those seriously injured included the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and the Vice-Minister of Finance.

The Governor-General and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) have both sent messages of condolence to President Chun. On behalf of the Australian Government and people they have expressed deep shock in learning of the tragedy which befell President Chun's party in Rangoon. They have conveyed our condolences to the Government and people of the Republic of Korea and reaffirmed Australia's support for the Republic of Korea at this troubled time. They have asked President Chun to convey to the families of those who died our deep sympathy and we have wished a speedy recovery to the injured.

These messages and the statements by the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Lionel Bowen) have pointed to the fact that a number of the people who died were known personally to us and other members of the Government.

President Chun had embarked on this overseas tour as part of the Republic of Korea's broadening of its contacts with the region. We had welcomed the growing role of the Republic of Korea in the region's affairs and the growing significance of its links with Australia. Since our Government took office we have had close and productive contact with the Republic of Korea.

Before the visit planned for next week by President Chun there had been four high level visits between Australia and Korea since this Government took office. In May the Secretary-General to the President, Dr Hahm Pyong Choon, visited Australia. He called on the Prime Minister and several other Ministers. Dr Hahm had been for many years one of the most articulate spokesmen for the Republic of Korea. He was formerly an Ambassador of the Republic of Korea to the United States. Dr Hahm died in Rangoon. His death is recognised by us as a great loss to his country and he will be remembered with respect. In July, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, visited Seoul. He talked then with President Chun, with Dr Hahm and with a number of others who died in Rangoon, including their distinguished Foreign Minister Mr Lee.

At the end of August-six weeks ago-the annual round of ministerial trade talks between the Republic of Korea and Australia took place in Canberra. The Leader of the Republic of Korea delegation was Mr Kim Dong Whie, Minister for Commerce and Industry and, at that time, I had the opportunity of lengthy discussions with him. Mr Kim had had a distinguished career in the foreign service and was until, his appointment as Minister, Permanent Head of the Korean Foreign Ministry. Mr Kim also died in Rangoon. He will be remembered not only as a friend and a tough bargainer for his country but also as a man of great enthusiasm and energy whose personal character contributed much to our relations .

Mr Suh Sang Chul, the Minister of Energy and Resources, had a particular connection and affection for Australia and had many friends here. Until several years ago Mr Suh was the Republic of Korea's representative at the World Bank in Washington. Australia and the Republic of Korea are members of the same constituency in the World Bank and so Mr Suh for several years worked closely with the Australian representative at the bank. Mr Suh also died in Rangoon. Among the officials who died, Mr Kim Jae Ik stood out as an outstanding technocrat of great intellectual ability who had many friends in Australia.

I have mentioned these names to provide some indication of the depth of personal connections developed between Australia and the Republic of Korea at a very high level and to underscore the personal loss that we share. The Republic of Korea has lost a number of its most important leaders. These were men of intelligence and vigor, among the brightest and most open minded of leaders in a society undergoing great changes. They will be very difficult to replace.

We also had been looking forward to President Chun's visit, in the expectation that it would contribute greatly to the growth of an already substantial and positive relationship. Australia has given consistent and principled support to the Republic of Korea for 35 years since its foundation in 1948. Australians fought and died in the Korean war. In a continued environment of hostility on the peninsula since then, South Korea has been obliged to maintain very large armed forces and there have been many difficulties and frustrations in the development of a more open political system. We nonetheless have remained confident, and continue to remain confident, that the basis for a strong, growing and beneficial relationship between our countries can be sustained.

The bomb explosion at the Martyrs' Mausoleum was a cruel blow. It has done nothing to contribute to a peaceful settlement of the problems of the Korean peninsula. It has deprived Korea of men of great experience and ability. No one can gain or draw satisfaction from this wanton act of terrorism. We can only hope that it will not irreversibly damage the cause of peace in an area where the balance of forces is otherwise so delicately poised.

We convey to the Korean people our profound sympathy. As a mark of our respect, the Deputy Prime Minister and Leader of the House, Mr Lionel Bowen, will leave Australia tonight to represent the Government at the memorial service to honour the dead. The honourable member for Hawker, Mr Jacobi, who is currently leading the Australian delegation to the Inter-Parliamentary Union conference in Seoul, will also attend the service.

We would also urge all nations with interests in the Korean peninsula to exercise restraint. The cost of the losses suffered to Korea and to all those with an interest in peace is already too high. They should not now be added to or compounded. I commend the motion to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition supports the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and joins with the Government in expressing its condolences and sympathy to the President and the people of the Republic of Korea. Yesterday, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, sent the following message to the President of the Republic of Korea:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Opposition expresses its sympathy to yourself, your Government and the people of the Republic of Korea. We extend our special condolences to the families of those killed in this tragic attack which has outraged the Australian people. I also extend my deep personal sympathy.

All Australians have been appalled by this assault on a presidential party comprising the highest holders of executive office in that nation. We have been reminded of the capacities of members of the President's party by the speech which has been just made by the Leader of the Government. Many were known in Australia to members of the Opposition. They were men of achievement and distinction who contributed to the singular success of the Republic of Korea's modernisation programs and the enhanced international stature of their country.

It is virtually without precedent that a nation has had much of its leadership destroyed while on a goodwill visit to another country. This, surely, must be one of the most ruthless acts of modern times. The Australian Government will have resources, including international contacts, which may help to bring to account those who perpetrated this dreadful deed. It is clear that it constitutes an affront to international morality of the utmost gravity and tragically it follows the shooting down of a Korean airliner just a few weeks ago. Increasing acts of violence and terrorism emphasise the importance of the international community uniting against those who would have recourse to such measures. Australia has an important role to play in this process. Clearly, in current circumstances, the Korean people need the reassurance of friends such as Australia and it is the wish of the Opposition that every effort be made by the Australian Government, in collaboration with Korea's other friends such as the United States of America and Japan, to bring to the Korean people in their moment of national distress the strength of Australia's sympathy and support.

This act of terrorism heightens the importance of maintaining a fundamental understanding of the role that the Republic of Korea has played in developing into a modern nation with an aspiration to play an increasingly constructive and creative part in world affairs. The purposes of this mission-to improve the links between the Korean people and Asian peoples of non-aligned pursuasion- remain as valid today as at the moment of inception. The goodwill of the people of the Republic of Korea, demonstrated in the decision to embark on this mission , has received a terrible set-back but it would be a very sad development for the world if the high purposes that President Chun had in mind were allowed to be dissipated by these events. The Republic of Korea has been a bastion of stability in north-east Asia, and this is sometimes overlooked by those who have expressed dissatisfaction at the pace of political development. But the contribution that the Republic of Korea makes to the security of the region, particularly Japan, is of the highest importance.

It is with regret that we have to accept the abandonment of the presidential visit and the cancellation of the tour of the Korean National Dance Company. When the time comes again for the visit to be reconsidered-and we hope that that will not be too far into the future-we on this side of the Senate would want the Korean people to be clear that Australia welcomes it. I am sure that many Australians who have had contact with the Republic would join the Government and the Opposition in this wish.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself and members of the Australian-Korean parliamentary group with the motion moved by the Leader of the Government (Senator Button) and seconded by the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Chaney). I was for some time president of that group. With a number of our colleagues, I visited Korea earlier this year and was able to meet the Foreign Minister and one or two other Ministers who met their deaths. I believe that our sympathy goes to their relatives who are left in these tragic circumstances. Earlier this year I was privileged to attend the South Korean Embassy with the Speaker of the House of Representatives and other distinguished guests and have dinner with Dr Hahm who, as the Leader of the Government said, was a most articulate representative of the Korean people. I believe it is tragic that this should have happened. I do not think that we in Australia appreciate the sensitivity of the political and military confrontation that takes place in that part of the world. Tragic events such as this recall to our minds how lucky we are to be so remote from that sort of confrontation. I am very pleased that Mr Jacobi, the President of the Korean-Australian Parliamentarians' Friendship Association, is able to make arrangements to attend the memorial service along with, I hope, some of our colleagues. I believe it is most important that we recognise the significance of the bond of friendship that has grown between Australia and the Republic of South Korea since the Korean War when Australia was to the forefront in defending that country against aggression from the north. On behalf of the Australian-Korean Parliamentarians Friendship Association, yesterday I sent a telegram to the Ambassador asking him to convey to the President of his Government our regrets at the barbaric act that resulted in the deaths of very prominent and respected Korean people.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The National Party of Australia in the Senate wishes to be associated with the motion moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and supports the thrust of it. Our leader, Mr Doug Anthony, will be supporting a similar motion in the House of Representatives. As Minister for Trade and Resources in the previous Government, he had many personal friends who were killed or severely injured in this outrage. At a time when there is a lot of misunderstanding and turmoil in the world it is important that world leaders, politicians and community leaders move around the world and try to cultivate a better understanding. It is, of course, a tragedy that this outrage happened on such an occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: Lest we get too complacent, may we be reminded that at an international conference held in Sydney not too many years ago something along this line could have happened in Australia. The fact that two innocent people who were going about their normal work were killed does not detract from the enormity of the intent of that bomb explosion there. In an age when this sort of thing is becoming all too prevalent, may we never cease to be outraged at the effrontery to honest, decent civilised people that such an explosion caused. Mr President, may you convey the sympathies of the National Party, along with all the others, to the relatives of those who were killed and to the people of Burma and the Republic of Korea.

TALK.START.PARA: —I associate the Australian Democrats with the terms of the motion as moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) and note in passing that less barbarous acts than this have led to and caused major conflagrations. We hope that this act by itself will not worsen the relationship between the Republic of Korea and its immediate neighbours.

—I wish to associate myself with the motion. In fact , I intend to support the motion wholeheartedly. I wish to place on record my support for the messages sent by the Governor-General and the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) as outlined in the speech by the Leader of the Government in the Senate ( Senator Button).

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. that the Tertiary Education Allowance Scheme (TEAS Allowance) has been progressively reducing in real terms throughout the 1980s, and is no longer at an adequate subsistence level.
2. that the situation where the independent TEAS allowance is substantially below the single, no dependant, unemployment benefit is inequitable and not supportable by cost relativities.
3. that the low level of TEAS allowance is detrimental to maintaining the proportion of students currently partaking in tertiary education.
4. that effective immediately the TEAS allowance should be increased to the same level as the single unemployment benefit and thereafter be maintained in line with changes in said benefits.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Brisbane Airport
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully shows:

We, the undersigned citizens of Australia, concerned with the cut in funding to the Brisbane Airport, concerned that this cut means loss of jobs, concerned that this cut could seriously affect the economy of Queensland:
Humbly petition the Senate to request the Australian Government to:
1. Reverse its decision to cut funding to the Brisbane Airport.
2. Abide by the guarantee given by the Minister for Housing and Construction that the Airport would receive priority funding.
3. Assure the citizens of Queensland that the Brisbane Airport as the domestic and economic gateway to this State will be fully completed by 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Discrimination against Women
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that whereas the Government of Australia has signed the United Nations Covenant on Civil and Political Rights which in Article 23 (1) states that 'The family is the natural and fundamental group unit of society and is entitled to the protection by society and the State', and
Whereas the terms of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women would violate the above Article 23 (1)
We humbly pray the Government to refrain from ratifying the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women, believing that its implementation would result in:
(1) Undue cost to the nation at this time.

(2) 'The elimination of any stereotyped concept of roles of men and women at all levels' as described in Part 3 Article 10 (c), being a disruption of traditional parental roles, is likely to result in emotional disturbances of childhood.

(3) The strong encouragements to mothers to join the workforce, with the provision of networks of creches and child care centres as outlined in article 11 of the convention is likely to result in maternal deprivation and psychological disturbances among children with an increase in childhood psychiatric illnesses.
(4) The sexual role changing as recommended in Part 3 Article 10 (c) is likely to contribute to further marriage insecurity and breakdown.
And we pray you may be conscious of God's sovereign purpose for our nation.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Nuclear Disarmament
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That your petitioners are concerned about foreign owned military bases on Australian territory and the entry into Australian waters and territory of foreign warships and aircraft carrying nuclear weaponry. And that the Australian Government should take an active and constructive role in the promotion of a nuclear-free world. Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should:
1. Promote the expression of Australian sovereignty by legislating to bring foreign military bases on Australian territory under the control of the Australian Government.

2. Make it compulsory that the disclosure of weaponry carried by foreign warships and aircraft be given in confidence to the Australian Government prior to a request for entry. And that foreign warships and aircraft that carry nuclear weaponry be banned from Australian waters and territory.
3. Legislate for the cessation of all uranium mining in Australia and its subsequent export.

4. Urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to pose to the Government of the United States and the Soviet Union that both countries agree to immediately halt the testing, production and further deployment of all nuclear weapons, missiles and delivery systems in a way that can be checked and verified by both sides.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

That the Sex Discrimination Bill 1983 contains provisions inconsistent with principles of justice and equality which could be used to

entrench abortion funding and render liable to action hospitals, doctors and nurses who conscientiously refuse to became involved in morally objectionable operations.

should amend the Bill so as to prevent the possibility of its use in the manner stated above and urge, because of the importance to society of the principles involved, that a conscience vote on the Bill be permitted to all members of Parliament.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS (NUCLEAR MATERIALS AND HARDWARE) PROHIBITION BILL 1983

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to prohibit the exportation of nuclear materials and the importation of nuclear hardware, and for purposes connected therewith.

TALK.START.PARA: —Does the Minister for Resources and Energy believe that the Leader of the Tasmanian Opposition, Mr Wriedt, is correct in saying, as he did on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio yesterday, that Australian Labor Party policy quite clearly prohibits development of any new uranium mines? If that is so, does he see that as being in conformity with the reported view of the Labor member for Kalgoorlie, Mr Campbell, that the left wing of the Labor Party, in opposing uranium development, has allowed itself, as Mr Campbell said, 'to become an irrational blancmange quivering in whatever mould the middle class trendies have chosen to pour it'? Does he dispute Mr Campbell's claim that Australia has the potential for a $1 billion a year industry and very large scale job creation through development of uranium deposits and the synroc waste disposal system?

—I was not aware of the statement made by Mr Wriedt. I will take Senator Chaney's word for it that he made it. Mr Wriedt is a State parliamentary Labor Party leader, but he is no longer a member of this Parliament or of the Federal Caucus and therefore will not be participating in the final decision on Government policy in this area when it is made by Caucus this month or perhaps early next month. I should like to see the context in which that remark was made . A quite common interpretation of the existing Labor Party platform is that it precludes the development of any new mines, except that there is the overriding clause 64C, I believe it is, which, although it does not explicitly refer to Roxby Downs, is generally conceded and is known by those who were actually present at the conference discussion to refer to Roxby Downs. This can be quite clearly seen from the transcripts, if anyone would like to check them. I am broadly aware of Graeme Campbell's views on the matter. I question very seriously the estimate of $1 billion a year additional income.
—He said 'a $1 billion a year industry . . . through development of uranium deposits and the synroc waste disposal system'.

—No time frame has been put on that. The present uranium exports have a value of about $350m. At some time in the distant future I expect it is conceivable that a billion dollars a year could be earned from export income. However, I believe that that is a very long way down the track and, without taking political considerations into account at all, very much further down the track than most people in, if one may use the term, the pro-uranium lobby will concede.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Attorney-General is aware of an article in the Perth Sunday Times of 25 September headlined 'Gems Bribe to Taxmen' wherein it was reported:

QUESTION.PARA: A startling new claim that tax department officials took diamond bribes to ignore a massive tax evasion racket has been made by runaway Perth financier Christo Moll.
Moll . . . told Channel Nine's Sixty Minutes that tax officers took bribes of diamonds worth $25,000 in 1977-78 . . .
The article went on to say:

The article further stated:
But the Dutch financier, who mixed regularly with Perth's jet-set, told Sixty Minutes that he was told to leave W.A. by his clients-who included members of the Western Australia Liberal Party.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have had the article to which Senator Cook refers drawn to my attention. I have no particular information on the specific matters he refers to in that article, although it is of course the case, as has been widely reported, that an ongoing and major investigation is proceeding under the auspices of the Australian Federal Police both in Australia and overseas. I will seek from the Special Minister of State any further particular information in relation to these matters that he is able to provide me with.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the question of an indemnity, I have not yet received any application for an indemnity either for or on behalf of Mr Moll, although one has again been widely foreshadowed in the media. In this respect again I am awaiting not only the formal receipt of such an application but more particularly a full report from the Australian Federal Police on all aspects of this matter. As honourable senators will be aware, the granting of an indemnity in a major criminal prosecution is not a matter that is entered into lightly at all. There are many criteria which have to be satisfied in a particular case before consideration can even be given to the granting of such an indemnity and that matter is simply not on my desk at the moment, although I expect it to be at some time in the reasonably foreseeable future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and relates to the statement by him to the Senate on 22 September on the matter of public duty and private interests. Specifically it refers to that part of his statement which says:

QUESTION.PARA: I shall be presenting a notice of motion today giving further details and proposing referral to the Standing Orders Committee for consideration and report .

But, as I recall, it is the intention of the Government that in respect of non-Ministers who are members of the Parliament the question which Senator Sir John Carrick quoted as one which should be addressed to the Standing Orders Committee should be addressed to the Standing Orders Committee and that consequent upon consideration of that matter by the Committee it would then be debated again in the Parliament.

—Has the Acting Minister for Health seen reports in the Tasmanian Press that a group of general practitioners intend to sabotage Medicare by refusing to bulk bill their patients? Who are these general practitioners and what is the possibility of their succeeding in their aims?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see and hear reports in the Tasmanian media of a meeting held in Hobart on the weekend after which it was announced that the group of general practitioners present would sabotage Medicare by refusing to bulk bill their patients. It turns out, in fact, that this meeting was organised by the General Practitioners Society in Australia. It was also paid for by various drug companies in this country. The General Practitioners Society is a small group of general practitioners; as well as being made up of doctors, it is an extreme right wing political group. In the words of some of my colleagues, it is to the right of the soup spoon.

ANSWER.PARA: Its members are mostly associated with right wing political parties in this country, such as the Workers Party and the Progress Party which seem to have gone the way of all such parties. They are opposed not only to Medicare but to any form of health insurance involving government in this country. In fact, they described the previous Government as a socialist government; at one stage they described it as more socialist than the Labor Government was when Mr Hayden was Minister for Social Security.

The great characteristic of this group, however, is that it will attempt to sabotage any health insurance program in this country, not at the expense of its members but at the expense of their patients. These practitioners will fight to the death against Medicare; they will fight to the last patient. They are never willing to make any sacrifices themselves. They claim that they will stop Medicare by depriving their patients-including their pensioner patients-of the privilege of being subject to bulk billing. They have done this since the organisation was inaugurated in 1974. They have failed to gain much support within the medical profession. They have gained considerable support from some members of the Opposition present, one of whom I notice has remained silent for the first time while I answer a question.

I believe that the organisation should be exposed for what it is-an extremist political organisation which is willing to take any steps to defeat the introduction of any health insurance scheme in this country, as long as those steps do not affect the incomes of its members or deprive them of any of the money they receive. They are not at all concerned about how they will inconvenience their patients in this regard. They are a disgrace to the medical profession. They are even a disgrace to the political profession. I believe that they will not succeed in their aims in this regard any more than they have in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Resources and Energy aware that nuclear energy contributes about 3 per cent of total energy supplies for the United States, a percentage which is roughly equivalent to the contribution made by firewood in that country? Is it the case that since 1978 no new nuclear reactors have been ordered for the United States and that all nuclear reactors ordered in the United States since 1974 have been cancelled? How does the Government assess the impact of this demise of the United States nuclear power industry on the demand for Australian uranium?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not able to confirm precisely the accuracy of the statement by Senator Macklin that nuclear energy in the United States contributes 3 per cent of that country's total energy supplies. When it is restricted to electricity-I acknowledge that there is a significant difference between the two -I think that, in the United States and in Western Europe generally, nuclear power supplies about 10 per cent of total electricity demand. I am not specifically aware either of whether there have been no new orders for nuclear reactors in the United States since 1978 or of whether all of those ordered since 1974 have been cancelled. However, in general terms I know that the construction rate for nuclear reactors which had been projected in the United States some years ago has been revised downwards very drastically, and that obviously has had an effect on the commercial demand for uranium which was anticipated at the time that forecasts for new reactor construction in the United States-and, I interpolate, in many other countries-were published some years ago.

ANSWER.PARA: Whether one should refer to the demise of the United States nuclear power industry I am not so sure; but certainly the deferral and/or cancellation in the United States, and in many other countries, of previously planned new nuclear reactors has had a substantial effect on the global commercial demand for uranium. That is a point that has been made frequently by me and by other members of the Government. My attention has been drawn to a very recent report, of which I have not yet been able to obtain a copy, of a paper delivered at a seminar in London recently at which it was predicted that there would be no additional commercial demand for Australian uranium for the rest of this century . The Government's assessment, up until now, has been that there would be no commercial demand for Australian uranium for the rest of this decade-at least additional to that which could be supplied from the two existing mines. But Senator Macklin's question, in general terms, correctly draws attention to the fact that the projections of demand for nuclear power which were commonly accepted some years ago are now known to be very substantial, if not gross, overestimates of the real commercial demand for uranium for at least the rest of this decade and maybe for the rest of this century. Obviously that has had implications for the potential-and again, I stress, independently of any political considerations-for the development of a uranium mining and/or processing industry in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the Minister seen Press reports that claim that the Government is softening the former Government's tough stand against apartheid? Can the Minister confirm or refute these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been speculation in the media that the Government will be softening its policies towards South Africa as a result of its reviews of civil aviation links between Australia and southern Africa and of sporting contacts with South Africa. There is absolutely no question of the Government relaxing its firm opposition to the evils of the apartheid system as practised by the South African Government. This has been stated many times. The Prime Minister made it quite clear in answering a question in the House of Representatives on 5 October. The Minister for Foreign Affairs, Mr Hayden, restated the Government's attitude towards apartheid in his address to the United Nations General Assembly last week. On behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, in this place, in answering a question two or three weeks ago, I made the same point.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government's review of policy on sporting contacts with South Africa has not yet been completed. That point does not seem to be appreciated by those who seek to criticise the Government. The objective of the policy review is simply to set out clear guidelines and to eliminate past inconsistencies. The Government has already expressed its strong opposition to apartheid in sport and its continued support for the Gleneagles declaration, and there will be absolutely no weakening of this position.

Concerning civil aviation, interim measures have been introduced for the convenience of passengers during the forthcoming peak holiday season. The Government's review of civil aviation links generally with southern Africa, however, has not yet been completed. I am sure that when it is completed there will, given the mood within the Government on this issue, be no basis whatever for any concern by those opponents of apartheid who are expressing that concern so volubly at present.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — My question, which refers to public duty and private interests, is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: Under the Government's disclosure requirements for Ministers, is it possible for a Minister with a family company or a trust to own any number of shares in any number of companies, public or private, without disclosing that ownership?

—I may have missed the last part of the question. Let me just paraphrase the question and then answer it, if I can. I am asked whether it is possible for a Minister, with a private company or trust, to own X number of shares and not--
—In any number of companies, without naming them .

—In any number of companies without naming them, without disclosing those interests. My answer is that I believe not and it is certainly the intention of the Government that that situation should be disclosed.
—In the register, in those published documents?
—Order! The Leader of the Government in the Senate is answering the question.

—I am just being assisted a bit. In endeavouring to answer the question, let me say that the Government's intention was that Ministers should disclose any interest in respect of which there may be a conflict, without indicating necessarily the extent of that interest.
—The value.
—The value of that interest, yes. So there is no requirement, I would imagine, that the precise numbers of shares at particular values be disclosed, but the interest should be disclosed.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to an answer given during Estimates committee hearings when advice was given that a surcharge of 60c is charged by doctors who treat veterans. Could the Minister give me an indication of the cost of this surcharge to the Government and what possible justification there is for paying it?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Robertson, during the Estimates Committee hearing relating to the Department of Veterans' Affairs, did ask a question about the justification for the Department paying an additional fee of 60c to local medical officers for every consultation or visit to a repatriation patient. I understand that the LMO scheme began in 1918 when, after the war, a whole number of veterans from World War I dispersed to country areas where they were not able to get ready access to the medical profession or to the facilities of the Repatriation Department, as it was then known. However, the situation has changed very considerably since then and, of course, in today's times, doctors do not have to look for business from repatriation or veteran patients. In fact, the converse is the case.

ANSWER.PARA: In looking at this matter, I have established that in the 1982-83 financial year the cost to my Department exceeded something like $1.7m. Consequently, one is entitled to examine whether that is a justifiable charge on expenditure, particularly when the Prime Minister has written to all Ministers asking them to establish a better system of savings in respect of expenditure. One is entitled, therefore, to look at this matter to see whether there is justification for this expenditure that has been with us for 65 years. The justification was that there were extra records and extra work involved by the local medical officer who was appointed by the Department. However, given recent developments in data storage and processing, as well as the volume of business which my Department now generates for local medical officers, it may well be that that margin, that payment of 60c per consultation, which is paid in respect of something like 2.8 million consultations a year, is rather difficult to justify in these economic times. I am currently examining the situation. I probably will have consultations not only with the Department but also with the medical profession to see whether in fact that expenditure is justified in today's conditions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Under the Government's disclosure requirements for Ministers, will the apparent position of a Minister with a $100 deposit in a bank account be the same as the apparent position of a Minister with a $1m deposit in a bank account ?

—The apparent position of a Minister with $100 in a bank account will be the same as the apparent position of a Minister with $1m in a bank account. The Government made it quite clear that the value of interests would not be disclosed by Ministers, and it is not suggested that it be disclosed by anybody else in the Parliament. If we think about our own case, as members of Parliament, there are very good reasons for that. The Government, after two inquiries established by the Parliament, one in 1975 which produced a unanimous conclusion, signed by Peter Nixon, James Killen and others, to the effect that there should be full disclosure of these matters--
—Full disclosure?
—Yes.
—Is that what you are advocating?

—No. If Senator Chaney would listen to the answer, he will learn that I am talking about what the report of the Riordan Joint Committee on Pecuniary Interests of Members of Parliament said. Senator Chaney's Government ignored that report for seven years. I also refer to the Bowen Committee of Inquiry concerning Public Duty and Private Interest, about which precious little was done by the conservative governments in this country. There is a lot of concern on the Opposition side in relation to the question of disclosure. As far as the Government is concerned, and it has been made quite clear since these returns were first disclosed, we are prepared to disclose all that we believe is necessary in order that people may make judgments about the two questions of pecuniary interests--
—Ten of you got it wrong.

—Yes, ten of us were wrong. All members of the Opposition are wrong at this stage because they have not disclosed anything. The intention of the Government was that Ministers should disclose all those matters which would enable people to make a judgment, firstly, about their pecuniary interests and, secondly, about a situation of conflict of interest in which they might be placed as Ministers of the Crown. We have invited members of the Opposition to do the same sort of thing, and I reissue that invitation. Finally, in relation to this whole debate, let us look at it this way: Let him who is without Sin- clair cast the first stone.

—I refer the Attorney-General to concern in the community that persons associated with the production of the film Allies have been smeared by allegations that they have been associated with the KGB. Can the Attorney- General say whether the Government has any evidence to support any such claim? If there is none, is he in a position to convey an apology to the people involved in respect of these allegations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware that an officer of the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation stated in evidence before the Hope Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies that ASIO had assessed the film Allies as being part of a KGB-backed disinformation operation. As a result of those references and certain other representations and questions that have been put to me, I have sought further information from the Director-General of ASIO. On the basis of the report I have received from the Director-General, I have now come to certain conclusions, which I think it is appropriate to put on the public record. While I can understand that there may have been reasons for suspicion on ASIO's part based on its previous experience of KGB disinformation activity, and on the previous activities of Mr Allan Francovich, the American who was billed as the co-producer of the film, it does not appear, on the information available to me, that there is evidence in this case which would sustain an assessment that this film was any part of such activity. In particular, I have seen no evidence to suggest that the funding for the film was raised otherwise than-as has been claimed by its producers-from ordinary investment sources within Australia.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have made clear in my own evidence to the Hope Royal Commission, I do not always draw the same inferences from available information as does ASIO. On the contrary, I consider it a vital part of the proper relationship between myself, on behalf of the Government, and ASIO that I be in a position to disagree on occasion with ASIO's assessments and recommendations, as I have done in this case so far as the particular evidence of the ASIO officer before the Hope Royal Commission was concerned.

Finally, may I say that, in a highly sensitive area such as this, where judgments made in good faith can nevertheless vary, I believe it is unfortunate, although probably inevitable, that this particular suggestion has received such widespread publicity to the understandable concern of the film makers and of other members of the public. I regret any embarrassment which this episode has caused to those associated in good faith with the film and I trust that my comments today have given them appropriate reassurance.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. I refer to Kate Legge's article in Friday's Age newspaper detailing a draft Cabinet submission which apparently seeks to exempt leisure equipment, which may include a holiday home, a caravan or a campervan but not a boat, up to the value of $30,000, from the proposed assets test. Does the Minister recognise the obvious inconsistency in exempting to a certain value these types of leisure items but exempting, regardless of value, items such as antiques, paintings and jewellery? Is this not another anomalous and iniquitous situation that the Government will build into the proposed assets test? Given the obvious continuation of the Government's ad hoc, piecemeal and confused approach to retirement income, will the Minister accede to my request to release the reports of the three working groups it established on retirement income policy so that the basis of its policy can be determined?

—Yes, I saw Kate Legge's article. As there is no Cabinet submission-the submission is not before Cabinet yet-I can assure Senator Messner that Kate Legge is talking about something which has not yet gone to Cabinet and , indeed, something which I and other Ministers have yet to finalise. I am very interested in the point that Senator Messner makes because the implication of what he says is the same as what his leader says; that is, that in fact we should assess and value all things in homes such as individual antiques and other such items. Of course, this would involve sending inspectors into every home in the country to have every bit of furniture and jewellery valued. If that is the sort of behaviour that Senator Messner and Mr Peacock want to introduce into this country, they can. But, rather than sit in here and snipe and carp about an assets test, Senator Messner should do what most other responsible people and organisations in this country have done, and that is to contact the Government about what he may or may not see as worries and we can have a discussion about them. I am even willing to do that with the honourable senator rather than have him come in here, or in public outside and worry individual pensioners in the way he is doing.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the light of the Minister's typical blustering reply, I just make the point that one of the best ways of making communication about any question at all is in this Parliament where the issues ought to be raised. Obviously this kind of question is not one that the Government wants to debate or else it would release the reports. I ask the Minister again to address himself to that part of the question.

—I apologise, Mr President. I omitted to answer that part of the question. My attitude to those reports will be exactly the same as my predecessor's attitude. They are Cabinet documents. The one which is not a Cabinet document is a working document of the Minister and it will not be released, unless it is released like the Spender report which was dropped off the back of a truck.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. The Minister for Primary Industry would be aware of, and no doubt disturbed by, the actions of the management of the Australian Wine Research Insitute when, in April this year, two long-serving scientists at the Institute were dismissed without warning and for no stated reason. The dismissals provoked a week-long strike by the employees at the Institute and the scientists association, the Association of Professional Scientists of Australia, sought reinstatement of the dismissed workers through arbitration. However, before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission the Institute argued that the case was a legal matter and this prevented Commission Neyland from making any recommendation. Is the Minister aware that since the dismissals in April the management of the Australian Wine Research Institute has continued to provoke further disputation by attempting to breach existing contracts of employment with remaining staff? Given that the Institute is funded primarily by the Federal Government, through the Department of Primary Industry and a statutory levy, does the Minister regard the Institute as a government body? If so, to what extent is the Government responsible for the proper running of the Institute? Is the Minister aware of the claim that the management of the Institute regards the Institute as a privately funded entity? Further, is the Minister aware that the Institute has moved unilaterally to alter the terms and conditions of employment of the Institute staff to lesser conditions? Is the Minister aware that, as a result of the actions by the management of the Institute, staff members have been forced into a legal battle with the Institute ? Is the Minister aware that government funds are being spent in this way by the Institute on attempts to downgrade the working conditions of Institute staff?
—Order! The honourable senator's question is a little too long.

—I am finishing now, Mr President. Is the Minister aware that the staff has repeatedly requested that an elected staff representative attend Council meetings to put forward its views on relevant matters and has as often been refused?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the strict technical sense, the Australian Wine Research Institute is not a government body in that it is in fact a company registered under South Australian company law. But it is correct, as Senator Crowley has stated, that it is funded substantially, if not primarily, by both direct general taxpayer contributions through the Commonwealth and by an industry levy. Therefore, as is usual with such institutes and such funding arrangements, the Minister for Primary Industry has some ministerial responsibility for the body to the degree to which the Commonwealth is involved in it. The Minister is aware and has been aware for some time of the unfortunate industrial relations situation which currently exists and has existed, I understand, for some time at the Institute. In response to that, the Minister has written to the Chairman of the Institute Council, which is the governing body, expressing his concern about the situation and requesting that the Council seek a mutually satisfactory resolution of the issue as quickly as possible.

ANSWER.PARA: At the Minister's request and, I expect, in response to that letter, a meeting is being arranged between members of the Council and officers of the departments of Employment and Industrial Relations and Primary Industry to establish the facts of the situation and to explore means of achieving a satisfactory resolution. I understand that that meeting is likely to take place this week although I cannot be sure of that. The Minister has indicated that he made clear to all the parties concerned his belief that they should achieve a settlement which is just, equitable and prompt.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . Does the Minister agree that, in general, Queensland coal mines are very low cost and thus more profitable operations than mines in New South Wales? Does he also agree that if the Commonwealth Government introduces a resource rent tax on coal, the Queensland mines will pay more tax than they do now while the New South Wales mines will pay less? Does this not mean that a resource rent tax on coal would result in more tax being paid in Queensland and less in New South Wales?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is correct as a generalisation that Queensland coal mines are lower cost than coal mines in New South Wales. It is possible that the lowest cost coal mines in the world, all things considered, are located in Queensland. It is correct that if the present industry levy system, including the rather rapacious rail freight charges of the Queensland State Government, were to be replaced by a tax aimed at economic rent, a tax more commonly, if not so accurately, described as a tax based on profits, low cost coal mines would pay at any given level of total industry taxation more tax than they currently pay and high cost coal mines would pay less. It follows from that that in periods of economic duress, such as that through which the industry is currently moving, higher cost coal mines would not unnecessarily be driven into a position of insolvency because of the charges which they must pay in common with low cost mines as some low cost mines are currently being driven into insolvency.

ANSWER.PARA: That much of Senator Martin's question is correct. The implication which she appears to have drawn from those facts, however, is not correct. The clear implication in or inference to be drawn from her question is that Queensland, as a State, will be disadvantaged if such a system of taxation were introduced. That is not correct because it would depend on who collected the tax. I have made it plain on a number of occasions that what I and the Government are primarily concerned about is not who actually imposes and administers the tax or receives the revenue; it is the system of taxation that matters. A change in the system of taxation towards a rent based tax as distinct from the prevailing overt and covert production based taxes would be to the advantage of the industry as a whole. But if Senator Martin has any difficulty in accepting the proposition that a change towards profits based taxes would be beneficial to the industry, I suggest she pursue that matter with the Liberal Party leader in her own State of Queensland who only last week stated, presumably--

TALK.START.PARA: —He is too busy calling Gray treacherous.

—Yes. He stated, presumably as the policy of the Queensland Liberal Party for the forthcoming election, that taxation of the coal industry should be changed in that way. I note two things: One, that such a view as expressed by Mr White is fully compatible with the policy being advocated by this Government--
—I take a point of order.
—Oh, the honourable senator does not like it.

—Mr President, I was going to ask a supplementary question. As Senator Walsh earlier seemed to have misunderstood my question, I was going to repeat the last part of it. What he is talking about now has nothing to do with what I asked. I asked: Does this not mean that a resource rent tax on coal will result in more tax being paid in Queensland and less in New South Wales? That is the question.
—There is no point of order.

—It would result in more. As I have already said, it would result at any given level of total industry taxation in more tax being paid by low cost mines and less tax being paid by high cost mines. The clear implication of Senator Martin's question, however, is that such a change would disadvantage the State of Queensland. I have already explained why that is not correct. The proposition that the system of taxation in regard to the coal industry ought to be changed apparently does not appeal to Senator Martin. I suggest that if that is the case she take it up with the leader of her own party in her own State who only last week advocated such a change. He advocated a policy change consistent with that being advocated by this Government and consistent, at least in broad terms, with what is being advocated by the Australian Labor Party leader in Queensland but which is at variance with the policies actually applied by successive Liberal Party Treasurers in the State of Queensland and former State Liberal parliamentary leaders in Queensland who, as always, were under the thumb of the Queensland National Party.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy . Is consideration being given to changing the restrictions on land development in the 1.6 kilometre to 4.8 kilometre area surrounding the Australian Atomic Energy Commission's research establishment at Lucas Heights? If so, what are these new restrictions? Why are they being altered? If the existing restrictions are to be lifted, does this mean that the Commonwealth will accept liability for any effect on the health and safety of residents living in the areas surrounding the Lucas Heights research establishment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The imposition of land use restrictions in the area surrounding the Lucas Heights establishment is strictly a matter for the New South Wales Government authorities, although the Atomic Energy Commission does provide technical advice to the New South Wales authorities. The present restrictions, based presumably on the advice of the Atomic Energy Commission, have been in force since 1967. Following the refurbishing of the HIFAR reactor, the Commission decided earlier this year, on technical grounds, that the continued operation of the reactor did not require any restrictions outside a 1.6 kilometre radius from the reactor. The Commission has recommended that the present 1.6 kilometre radius exclusion zone be retained. The Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Commonwealth-State Relations, Mr Lionel Bowen, wrote to the Acting Premier of New South Wales in June advising him of the Atomic Energy Commission's decision, but whether there is, consequential to that advice, any change in the present land use restrictions is, I emphasise, entirely a matter for the Government of New South Wales.

ANSWER.PARA: In response to the last part of the question, the Atomic Energy Commission would accept liability under common law for any effects on local residents and property resulting from the Commission's operations, irrespective of whether the land use restrictions were lifted or changed. I am informed that the former Treasurer, in answer to a question on 21 October last year, indicated that the Commonwealth would stand by the Commission in respect of any damages awarded against it under common law. I would expect this Government to stand by that undertaking in the unlikely event of such action being taken and being successful.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIA AND ASSOCIATION OF SOUTH EAST ASIAN NATIONS

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. It concerns the disturbing development in the delicate and important relationship between Australia and our northern neighbours, the countries of the Association of South East Asian Nations. Is the Minister aware of the rift that is developing between Australia and the nations of ASEAN, that there has been talk of sanctions being introduced by ASEAN against Australia and that ASEAN has actually deferred consultations between Australia and ASEAN at senior official level, talks which had been scheduled for later this month? Can the Minister explain why Mr Hayden has repeatedly said that Australia will not sponsor the United Nations resolution for the withdrawal of foreign forces from Kampuchea and for free elections to decide the future of Kampuchea, as Australia has done in past years? Why has the Foreign Minister given no adequate reason for this dramatic change in foreign policy, even on his current brief visit to Australia? Is the Minister aware that some of the ASEAN countries feel that Australia should be consistent on this matter and that, if the Australian Government will not sponsor the measure which has been specially redrafted to meet Australian requirements, then it should also vote against the resolution? Will the Minister tell the Senate of the real situation? Are we really on the side of the Soviet Union, as Thailand and Singapore have come to believe?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Developments in recent days, despite some Press reports to the contrary, certainly do not justify the description 'disturbing' which was given to them by the honourable senator, let alone some of the more extravagant commentary which then followed later in his question. As I am advised by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the situation is this: While Australia does not propose this year to co-sponsor the ASEAN resolution on the situation in Kampuchea, for reasons which I will come to in a moment, Australia does, of course, intend to vote for that resolution because it supports the following: The withdrawal of Vietnamese troops; an act of self-determination by the Cambodian people; guaranteed borders for all territories in the region; and the re-establishment of a normal relationship between the countries of the region.

ANSWER.PARA: The fact of our not co-sponsoring this year should not be blown out of proportion. The terms of the resolution are not the same as they were last year. There are a number of assertions contained in the resolution as to matters of fact, or matters which are stated to be matters of fact, relating to the Vietnamisation of Kampuchea and the success of the present coalition group within Kampuchea to which Australia is not prepared to accede to the extent of co-sponsoring the resolution in question. Australians, furthermore, have certainly not forgotten the brutal Khmer Rouge regime in Cambodia under Pol Pot. The Pol Pot forces make up the largest part of the coalition now very overtly supported in the ASEAN resolution. To put this matter further in context, it needs to be appreciated that a number of important countries very friendly to ASEAN did not co-sponsor the resolution. These included the United States of America, China, France, Austria, Sweden, Denmark, Norway, Ireland, Greece, Burma , Saudi Arabia and Egypt. I inform the honourable senator that the only new co- sponsor at this stage is the Maldives.

We have to recognise that where we have a policy which is carefully reasoned, is thoroughly responsible, is moderate in its presentation, and which is appropriate in all the circumstances, then if that policy expressed in those terms is in our national interest we should persist with it. Some of the Press items, I am instructed, have very considerably exaggerated current differences between Australia and ASEAN over the handling of the Cambodia issue at the United Nations. Reports, for example, that the Malaysian Foreign Minister walked out of the United Nations chamber before Mr Hayden had finished his General Assembly address completely misinterpreted what occurred. The Minister in question left the Assembly hall earlier because a Peruvian delegate had wildly overrun his speaking time. The Malaysian Minister in question was obliged to attend a luncheon, at which Mr Hayden subsequently arrived and sat next to the Malaysian Minister, who immediately apologised for having to walk out of the chamber when he did because he was enormously interested in the content of Mr Hayden's speech.

We understand that the ASEAN countries wish to postpone the ASEAN-Australia forum of senior officials in Sydney later this month. That is regrettable but, nonetheless, the relationship is in thoroughly good shape. Differences of emphasis with ASEAN are not new. It will be recalled that there was a far more strident reaction in previous situations, such as the question of the Khmer Rouge's United Nations credentials when Australia, under the last Government, took a policy on that, and on matters of civil aviation policy.

Finally, on behalf of the Foreign Minister I say that it is a healthy part of all robust relationships, including our close and wide-ranging links with ASEAN, that genuine differences of perception occur from time to time. We are not claiming that solutions to the Cambodian problem can be quick or simple. Of course, we recognise ASEAN's continuing role in that respect.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to you, Mr President, and refers to Joint House Department circulars giving notice of pest control treatment of the parliamentary refreshment rooms on 23 and 30 September. What pest control agents were used and for what purpose? What quantities of agents were used and how were they applied? How often is it intended that these areas will be treated? On what occasions has East Block been treated for pest control since November 1982? Are there any plans for future treatment?
—I will obtain the information for the honourable senator and advise the Senate subsequently.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Education. I refer to the Minister's address at Hurstville two weeks ago where, it is reported, she directly attacked the well-established principle that taxpayers may expect some support from the taxes they pay to cover at least some of the costs of their children's education. Is it true that the Government has now completely abandoned this principle? Is it also true that the Minister called this principle 'a specious argument'? What was the Minister's response when those offended by this attack on taxpayers described the Minister's view as specious, ideologically subjective and sectionally political? Finally, does the Government threaten to carry the abandonment of this taxpayers' principle to health with regard to non-government hospitals and the abandonment of any other provisions which currently accrue as benefits to all taxpayers and not just to those taxpayers whom the Labor Government chooses to serve?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In reply to that very long and convoluted series of questions and accusations I will try to clarify the point I was making when I addressed a very large meeting of Anglican schools in Hurstville recently. I pointed out our view that being a taxpayer does not of itself automatically entitle one to total subsidy if one chooses a service outside the public service.
—Some subsidy.
—Order! Senator Teague, you have asked your question. I call the Minister.

—The question arises because some people have criticised our decision to reduce very moderately the Commonwealth grants to some private schools as being a denial of the rights of taxpayers. Let me make a couple of things clear: First of all, the extent of Commonwealth subsidy to private schools is still considerable. There is still several hundred dollars going to each child, even in the very well resourced private schools, so there is no question of those taxpayers receiving no assistance. It is still the case that every non-government school in Australia is receiving substantial Commonwealth and State subsidies. I do not accept the argument and the Government does not accept the argument that because a person is a taxpayer he or she is automatically entitled to a total subsidy of a service he or she chooses to take in the private sector.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Ryan, please address your remarks to the Chair and ignore the interjections.
—It is the case that the Commonwealth is prepared to subsidise private choice in regard to education on a needs basis.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I interjected because the Minister answered a different question from that which I asked. So I ask the supplementary question: Does the Government now abandon the principle that taxpayers can expect some support from the taxes they pay to cover at least some of the costs of their children's education?

—No, the Government does not do whatever it is Senator Teague is implying it is trying to do. I refer him to the speech I made when we debated a matter of public importance on the question of the funding of non-government schools in this chamber some weeks ago, when I set out very clearly the way in which the Government currently subsidises the choice of those people who choose education outside the government system.
—The Government does not subsidise it; the taxpayers subsidise it.
—I also refer Senator Withers to that debate.

—I direct my question to the Acting Minister for Health. Is it a fact that the new Calaid frequency modulation hearing aid will not be available to patients in the Northern Territory as claimed by the Northern Territory Minister for Health, Hon. Nick Dondas?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it is not true, and Mr Dondas knows it is not true. The Calaid FM hearing aid has been a very important development of the National Acoustic Laboratories and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Some 30 are being released this month for field testing. It is terribly important that as part of that field testing they be tested in tropical areas. As a result of that, I think, two are being tested in the Northern Territory, which is the same number as are being tested in Western Australia and Tasmania.

ANSWER.PARA: After the tests have been completed and the producer has established its production lines effectively, some 6,000 of these very important but expensive hearing aids will be distributed throughout Australia. It just demonstrates that Mr Dondas is willing to use the disabled in the Northern Territory for his own political ends and to create unnecessary anxiety amongst the families of the disabled. As Senator Robertson says, it is despicable behaviour.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. It follows the question asked earlier in Question Time by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle about pecuniary interests of members of parliament and the disclosure of those interests. I ask the question to seek clarification of the reply given by the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I ask: Under the guidelines which the Government has laid down, are Ministers obliged to disclose shareholdings in public and private companies when such shareholdings are held by a private company or a family trust which is owned or part owned by a Minister? If they are so obliged, does the Leader of the Government in the Senate say that Ministers have disclosed all such shareholdings in the returns tabled by him?

—I would like to examine Senator Chaney's question in detail and provide him with a quite lucid and explicit answer, but let me say that insofar as shareholdings in public companies are concerned I understand the principle to be that those matters be on the public record. If a Minister is a shareholder in a public company or a director of a public company the question of the shareholdings of that company is a matter of public record. That is the desirable principle which the Government seeks to establish.
—If he holds them through a family trust?

—Of course, if the Minister is a shareholder through a family trust, the shareholdings of the company are matters of public record. With regard to the question of private companies, I would like to refresh my memory because I do not want in any way to mislead the Senate in this matter. It is clearly a source of concern to many senators and we in the Government are concerned that we get it right. There is no desire to hide anything. There is rather a desire to see that we can work together towards a system which ensures that all Ministers and senators disclose the interests which might bring them into public conflict of interest or disrepute.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the same spirit of wishing to get considered replies, I ask the Leader of the Government to consider all the replies which he has given on this matter and to let the Senate know if there is any element in what he has said that he wishes to correct, preferably by tomorrow.
—Okay.

TALK.START.PARA: —We now proceed to General Business notice of motion No. 39 standing in the name of Senator Georges relating to meetings of the Joint Statutory Committee of Public Accounts. Is that formal or not formal?
