SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The action of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) in declaring the matter 'not formal' means that the motion of which I gave notice will now go on to the Notice Paper and we may not debate it for some time. The purpose of the notice of motion was to bring before the Senate the request of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to sit tomorrow, Wednesday, and again the following Wednesday. As I have stated before, the Public Accounts Committee now is faced with great difficulty in carrying out its program because of decisions taken by the Senate. I do not doubt that the Leader of the Opposition has objected to those decisions which have extended the sitting times of the Senate in such a way that they have interfered with the work of committees. They have certainly interfered with the work of the Public Accounts Committee which now finds its program, in some cases, almost two years behind because of the election and other matters. It is necessary for the Public Accounts Committee to carry out the work that the Parliament has given to it. Both the House of Representatives and the Senate have given the Public Accounts Committee a program which derives from the Auditor-General's report. I notice that today you, Mr President, have put down further material from the Auditor- General. That will add to the work of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is a statutory committee which operates under an Act of Parliament and is directly responsible to the Parliament for its work. It is not that it is not endeavouring to meet the wishes of the Senate provided for by one of its standing orders, which has recently been looked at by the Senate Standing Orders Committee. The Public Accounts Committee now sits on Tuesday night. It will sit tonight from 8 o'clock possibly until 11 o'clock. Tomorrow we intend to have witnesses appear before the Committee and that would take us through until 1 o'clock or not much later than 1 o'clock. So what we are asking for is the facility to sit the extra time in order to carry out our work. We will sit again on Thursday. On Thursday we will conform to the standing order of the Senate which says that we shall not sit after the Senate is called together. But nevertheless we do sit in order to carry out certain formalities of the Committee and to facilitate its program. The Senate also decided that it would sit every second Friday. That means the work of the Committee has been further constrained because Friday was the day on which we carried out our field work. This is a committee which is endeavouring to carry out its work and it now appears that it is to be frustrated in that endeavour by the Leader of the Opposition. I know the Leader of the Opposition well enough to appreciate that he would not frustrate the work of the Public Accounts Committee, which is concerned with the supervision of the financial efficiency of a variety of departments. I know that he would not do that, so he must have some other purpose in mind. Could I suggest to him that he ought to put those other considerations to one side and allow the Public Accounts Committee to meet in order to carry out its work. It cannot do so at the present time.

The Public Accounts Committee will bring before the Senate, I trust in time, after it has been discussed at various levels, a request to enlarge the size of the Committee so that it may break up into various sub-committees. At the present time it has three sub-committees operating. Two inquiries are being carried out at the one time. We still cannot manage our work under the constraints which are now being imposed upon us. We will seek to increase the size of the Committee and that is a matter which I hope in time will come before the Senate.

I put down an opinion, which I think has gone before the Standing Orders Committee, and the Committee has considered that opinion. The matter has not been debated, so perhaps I ought not to go too far. But there is some recommendation which the Standing Orders Committee will bring before the Senate which says that the Standing Orders of the Senate ought to be observed and that subsequently the matter be clarified by amendment to the Act. I know that is there but, out of courtesy to the Senate, until the matter is resolved, I decided this time to bring this matter before the Senate by way of notice of motion. I had hoped by so doing that the Leader of the Opposition would allow that matter to go through formally. What he has done today is exactly what he did on the previous occasion, that is, to refuse leave. He has now, by asking that this matter be declared not formal, done exactly the same thing; in other words, frustrated the Public Accounts Committee from doing its work. All I am suggesting to the Leader of the Opposition is that if that is the position he wants to take then we shall have to, by debate and comment and statement, point out that the Opposition in the Senate is preventing the Public Accounts Committee from carrying out its program. What he is saying to us now is that the investigation by the Committee of the Auditor-General's report on the Department of Defence shall be delayed. This is a very important report. It refers to HMAS Tobruk. Consideration of this report will have to be deferred. The investigation of the gathering of excise in this country, which is a very important reference before the Committee, will have to be further postponed so that revenue to which this nation is entitled will continue, in some way, to be lost to the Treasury, mainly because of the obstruction that we are now being faced with in the Senate . The medifraud inquiry is still in the process of being further investigated. We are looking at patient fraud, fraud in private hospitals and over-servicing in the area of doctors' activities by way of unnecessary operations. All of these inquiries are before the Committee and we cannot at this stage carry out that program effectively. I am saying to the Leader of the Opposition that we are not asking for the right to leave the Parliament or to leave this House to carry out our inquiries. We are not even asking for pairs. We are merely asking for the right which was given to us by the House of Representatives to sit while the Senate is sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the House of Representatives agreed?

—The House of Representatives agrees, but every time we sit everything that we do before that Committee is subject to considerable doubt. It is even subject to the matter of privilege. If we were to get a witness before the Committee at this stage and sit without the consent of the Senate, until the matter is determined there is some doubt as to whether those proceedings are valid and whether privilege prevails. So we are in great difficulties. We will sit tomorrow, we have no option. We will sit until the Senate makes a determination on this investigation before the Standing Orders Committee. But if we sit tomorrow and we have a witness before us who says some things which are subsequently reported and the Senate's desire that the Standing Orders should prevail is subsequently upheld, all that evidence before the Committee is not covered by privilege. In fact, according to the standing order of the Committee, that meeting is null and void. I am suggesting to the Leader of the Opposition that he should think again before he determines on the course of declaring this matter informal. Perhaps he could allow the matter to be put again and the matter to be declared formal so that the Senate can determine it. I believe the Senate will give permission to the Public Accounts Committee to sit tomorrow and the following Wednesday. The Public Accounts Committee, until the matter is determined, will continue to seek permission of the Senate to sit. But if it is to be obstructed in this way then it has no other option. But at least tomorrow' s meeting will have to be held, in spite of the risks which are entailed. There are other means that I could take to bring the matter to a decision. I am not prepared to do that because I cannot take the business of this House out of the hands of the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) or the Whip . I could move that so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent me from moving this motion. I could do that now, but I have not discussed it with the Leader of the Government in the Senate or with the Whip. I am not in a position now to move that proposition in order to frustrate the Leader of the Opposition. I come back to the plea to the Leader of the Opposition-
—You would certainly have our support.
—I believe I have the support of the majority of the Senate. All I am suggesting is that the Leader of the Opposition think again and allow this proposition to pass.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Last week Senator Georges told me that he was proposing to give notice of motion in regard to the matters he has raised and we had some discussion on them. At that time I said that I thought that was the appropriate procedure for him to follow rather than seeking leave, as he had in the past, and I undertook to raise the matter again in the Opposition party room. I have not had an opportunity to discuss that further with Senator Georges because we met just prior to lunch and I was engaged right up to the time of this sitting.

SPEECH.PARA: The Opposition has given the matter further consideration and stands by the position I outlined on behalf of the Opposition on a prior occasion, namely, that it believes that the principle that committees should not sit during sittings of the Senate is one that we should seek to uphold and maintain. We do not take the view that that is a principle which applies without any exception. Indeed, within the last couple of months we have joined with the Government in agreeing to the sitting of a Senate committee-the Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations-during two of the Senate's sitting days. We did that because the Senate itself had put a time limit on the deliberations of the Finance and Government Operations Committee with respect to its inquiry into withholding tax. That was necessary in order for us to be effective in our work and we regarded that as an undesirable but permissible exception.

In the present case we face the situation where in many respects the present sittings of the Parliament give rise to enormous inconvenience. In my own case, I have to leave Western Australia at midday on Sunday at the latest in order to be able to meet my duties in this place. That is because the Government has changed the sitting pattern to remove one of the free mornings which were available under past sitting programs for party or shadow Cabinet meetings. I give that as just one further example, on top of the example given by Senator Georges, of the inconvenience which is currently being occasioned. It is the view of the Opposition that we should not start to allow breaches of the principle that Senate committees should not sit while the Senate itself is sitting just because we have an inconvenient set of sitting hours and it is difficult for committees, and indeed all of the organisations that surround this Parliament, to operate. So, Mr President, we take the view that it is--

TALK.START.PARA: —When would you suggest that committees should sit?

—I hear the interjection from behind me. I did not set these sitting hours; the Government set them, and it had a great deal of co-operation from the Australian Democrats in getting the sitting hours it wanted. Quite frankly, I think that is a problem which has to be ironed out. We do not believe it is properly to be ironed out by having any committees-joint committees, Senate committees or whatever-sitting while this chamber is sitting. Mr President, if you look at the time that has been requested by Senator Georges you will see that he is seeking a right for a Senate committee to sit tomorrow. Tomorrow the Senate will be considering constitutional legislation. It will consider a series of Bills, put forward by the Government and some honourable senators, seeking amendments to the Constitution. After that we will consider some highly contentious legislation with respect to taxation law which is the subject of very considerable concern and interest in the community. To suggest that the Public Accounts Committee should carry on its separate work at a time when this chamber is dealing with major issues which face the Australian people is self-evidently a false proposition.
—All your senators will be in the chamber during that debate, will they?

—There have been a lot more Opposition senators than Government senators in this chamber over recent weeks. There has been a particularly poor attendance in the chamber. I believe one should not run this place on the assumption that honourable senators should have their heads down in committee meetings, where they cannot possibly be keeping up with what is happening in the chamber and where they cannot be doing their duty by the chamber. Whilst the Opposition sympathises with the plight of the Public Accounts Committee, it says that the Public Accounts Committee is but one body which is facing difficulties under the present sitting hours. Members of the Opposition do not propose to facilitate the extension of what we see as a bad principle, namely, to have committees sitting while the Senate is sitting.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-May I say that I appreciate that attempts have been made over some weeks to conciliate this matter and I have had discussions with the Leader of the Opposition, Senator Chaney, about it. I have also had discussions with Senator Georges about it.
—And correspondence.

—And correspondence. It is now reaching the proportions of a Dreyfus case which has to be resolved. Let me say that this matter was considered by the Standing Orders Committee. Senator Chaney was not able to be there that night; I understand he had a dinner engagement, which is something that happens to us all in the Senate. We are often not able to attend because of other engagements.
—It was a royal command; it was with the President.

—Senator Chaney says it was a royal command, with the President. The President was able to be at the meeting. I take it he left his guests behind . On all these occasions there are difficulties of that kind which honourable senators have to confront. I must say I am not persuaded by Senator Chaney's resolute display of piety on this matter. Frankly, I do not see the connection between the general question of sitting hours and the sittings of the Joint Committee on Public Works, although honourable senators have sought to make that point on numerous occasions. I have the gravest difficulty in seeing what sitting hours Senator Chaney suggests would accommodate Senator Georges's problem. Certainly no sitting hours that we have had since I have been here would have accomodated the question of the sittings of the Public Accounts Committee.
—It always has in the past.

—No, it has not. I was referring to the meeting of the Standing Orders Committe of the Senate. At that meeting it was agreed that the Public Accounts Committee should be considered in the same way as the Public Works Committee, which has a legislative provision which enables it to sit during parliamentary sessions with the leave of the Senate. The consensus, if not the unanimous view, of the Standing Orders Committee was that the same sort of provision should apply in respect of the Public Accounts Commitee, and that until such time as the legislation could be amended in order to make that provision for the Public Accounts Committee the same practice should apply and the Public Accounts Committtee should be able to sit with the leave of the Senate.
—We have not debated the report of that Committee. I am anxious to see the report and debate it.

—I understand that. Senator Harradine is anxious to see the report and debate it. I am sure we all are; it is a scintillating topic. We discussed it for a couple of hours. The only point I seek to make, having due regard to the fact that the deliberations of the full Senate on that question have not yet been heard, is that that was the spirit with which the Standing Orders Committee approached the problem. In my view it is the spirit in which the Senate should approach the contemporary problem of the Public Accounts Committee, which has sought the leave of the Senate to sit on two occasions, namely, tomorrow and some subsequent Wednesday. And that is the subject of Senator Georges's motion. I regret the attitude of the Leader of the Opposition in the sense that we have, I believe, made a quite genuine attempt to accommodate the Opposition on the longer term question of hours and will continue to do so. I really do not see a very powerful connection between this mini-problem and the overall question of the Senate hours. I believe that Senator Georges's motion should be adopted.
—Are you calling Senator Georges a mini-problem?

—If I might rephrase that, in view of the interjection, some might think it a mini-problem but it has been raised to great magnitude by Senator Georges's eloquence. I believe that issue ought to be resolved and at the placing of business I will move to give the Senate the opportunity to resolve it.

PROCTEXT.PARA: That, intervening business be postponed until after the consideration of General Business notice of motion No. 39 standing in the name of Senator Georges relating to the sitting of the Public Accounts Committee and also order of the day No. 84 standing in the name of Senator Bolkus relating to a proposed reference to the Standing Committee on Privileges.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have tried to outline to the Senate why the Opposition thinks that we should not deal with this motion and why the motion should not meet with the agreement of the Senate. The fact is that the sitting hours of the Senate remain in the hands of the Government. The Government has chosen to vary the sitting pattern and to produce a longer period of hours in the week than has been traditionally required. That has put a number of different parts of the Parliament at a considerable disadvantage. For example, it has disadvantaged the shadow Cabinet; it has disadvantaged the Opposition parties; it has disadvantaged the Joint Committee on Public Works--
—And the Government.

—I now have an interjection from the Leader of the Government that it has disadvantaged the Government. That makes it very hard to understand why we are all suffering this disadvantage since it seems to be shared equally around the Parliament. The fact is that we believe that the general principle of maintaining sittings of parliamentary committees outside the timetable of the Parliament is a principle which should be upheld. We particularly believe that the arrangements which this Government has introduced should not be used as an excuse to break that principle. On behalf of the Opposition I oppose the motion which has been moved by the Leader of the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too oppose the motion on the ground that it is putting the cart before the horse. It appears that the matter relating to the sitting of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts was considered by the Standing Orders Committee. There has been no debate in the Parliament as yet on the report of the Standing Orders Committee. Proposing this motion now is pre- empting a proper and deliberative debate on that matter to which the Standing Orders Committee has addressed itself. That is the reason that I oppose this motion at this stage. If the motion is carried, I will have something more to say about the essence of the proposition put forward by Senator Georges, which is a different matter.

That the motion (Senator Button's) be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent such senators as are members of the Joint Statutory Committee of Public Accounts attending meetings of the Committee during sittings of the Senate on Wednesday, 12 October and Wednesday, 19 October 1983.
I have already made a speech on this subject.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition is opposed to the motion which has been moved by Senator Georges because we do not believe that it is appropriate for the Joint Committee of Public Accounts to be sitting tomorrow when the Senate has major items of business before it, namely, constitutional amendments and income tax legislation . We believe that committees of the Parliament, like committees of the Senate, should find times during the week which are not part of the parliamentary sitting time in which to transact their business. Whilst I have been complaining about the sitting hours which have been laid down by the Government-I intend to go on complaining about them until the Government completes its exercise in finding a more sensible set of sitting hours which will meet the needs of the Parliament, the parliamentary committees and the parties which operate here-the fact of the matter is that there are plenty of times during the week when this Parliament is not sitting and when the Public Accounts Committee could transact its business. There is, for example, all day on Mondays. Even with the sitting hours and days which are proposed by this Government Mondays are left free. I commend to the Public Accounts Committee the use of Mondays when we are not dealing with constitutional matters in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: I also refer the members of that Committee to the freedom of Tuesday mornings. Tuesday mornings are free of parliamentary business and are available to the Public Accounts Committee. I commend Tuesday mornings to the Committee. I see that Senator Georges is shaking his head. Senator Georges, of course, as a good Labor man has to go to his Caucus meeting on Tuesday mornings. The fact of the matter is that all of the members of the Public Accounts Committee would not agree to sit on Tuesday mornings because their parliamentary parties meet then. That gives honourable senators a fair idea of the sorts of priorities that exist in this Parliament. None of them will ask to sit on Tuesday mornings when their precious Caucus or parliamentary party is meeting. Instead they say: 'Oh no, let 's sit while the institution to which we are elected, which we are paid to attend and in whose deliberations we are supposed to take part is meeting. Let's have our parliamentary committee meetings then.' I commend Tuesday mornings as a possible time for the Public Accounts Committee to meet. If it is looking for time, why does it not try sitting on Tuesday evenings? Under the arrangements which have been entered into, Tuesday evenings are free. The Public Accounts Committee could meet on Wednesday mornings until 10 o'clock. That is not a bad time for it to use if it wants to. It could meet on Thursday evenings or all day on Fridays.

In terms of available time which is not parliamentary sitting time, the fact of the matter is that plenty of alternatives are available. The fact of the matter is that the Public Accounts Committee is seeking to sit on Wednesdays because that would be less inconvenient to the Committee. Some Committee members would rather miss Parliament than miss Caucus meetings. They would rather miss Parliament than have to leave home at midday on Sundays which, I suggest, is an excellent way to start the week. The Opposition is not moved by what has been said by Senator Georges. The fact of the matter is that this motion is a very good indication of the priorities which people are developing in this Parliament . The last priority is this chamber, which is supposed to be the place that has some authority. As it is, we will debate major constitutional issues. We will debate issues of taxation which go to concerns of many Australians and we will do it to a near empty chamber because Senator Georges and his colleagues want to be somewhere else ferreting about, working out what has gone wrong with the administration of the law. Maybe they should be here, Mr President, trying to ensure that we do not pass stupid laws which are wrong and which give rise to problems of all different sorts. On behalf of the Opposition, I firmly oppose the proposition which is before us. We do not believe that it is desirable in principle for parliamentary committees to meet while the chambers are in session . For that reason, we oppose the motion which has been moved by Senator Georges.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I can understand the concern so eloquently expressed by Senator Georges and also the legal implications that he, as Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, must consider. But there seems to be a conflict of interest between the duties that are imposed upon Senator Georges as Chairman and the other members of the Public Accounts Committee and their duties as members of this chamber. I believe it would be unfair to the individual members of the Committee for the Senate to agree to the motion before us at this time as it is constructed. We have been given some indication by Senator Georges of the times that the Public Accounts Committee desires to meet. It is obvious that those times will coincide, both tomorrow and on Wednesday of next week, with times when matters of major national importance will be debated in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: As the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) said, tomorrow matters of very major importance relating to the Constitution of this nation will be debated and determined. Another matter listed for consideration relates to taxation. It has been evident in previous debates on both of these major matters that adherents of the political parties have taken for granted what has been stated by their Ministers in the case of the tax matter or by their Ministers or shadow Ministers in the case of the other matter. The proposal would be unfair to those members because they would not be able to hear for themselves the arguments advanced in this chamber on these matters of national importance, one of which they will have to defend before the people when the referendum is held.

On Wednesday of next week it appears that we will be considering the sex discrimination legislation. Would it be fair to individual members if they were not present for that debate? We will be considering the sex discrimination legislation and the House of Representatives will most likely be considering the family law legislation. Both pieces of legislation raise matters of very grave importance to the social fabric of this society. Not only that; they are matters of importance to the individual consciences of the members of the Public Accounts Committee. Therefore, I feel it would be unfair to deny the members of the Public Accounts Committee the opportunity to be informed in a way that would not be available to them in the Caucus room.

TALK.START.PARA: —Great speech, Senator.

—Since Senator Button interjects, I take up the point he made about the spirit which was abroad in the meeting of the Senate Standing Orders Committee when this whole question was being debated. I reiterate that we seem to be putting the cart before the horse. We should have had before us for debate the report of the Standing Orders Committee-
—The spirit before the bottle.

—Before we make a decision on this matter. Yes, there was apparently a great spirit abroad. For the Leader of the Government's information , we are faced with the problem of having to be in two places at the one time. That problem could be overcome by a gift more likely to be found with spirits than with us mere mortals; namely, the gift of bi-location.
—I call Senator Georges.
—I will be closing the debate.
—Does anyone else wish to speak?
—I have the call.
—I call Senator Lewis.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise-
—You realise, of course, that you take away the time that we need?
—Order! I have called Senator Lewis.

—Thank you, Mr President. I rise to support what Senator Chaney and Senator Harradine have said. I am reminded of something that Senator Harradine said here last year in relation to committees. He said: 'I am going to institute a committee called the Senate'.
—Yes, I forgot that.

—I am sorry to remind the honourable senator. It seems to me to be very important that a committee of 64 senators should be meeting and debating matters that are, as Senator Harradine says, of vital interest to this nation. Honourable senators should not be wandering off to committee meetings at times that suit them. I am a member of a number of committees. SPEECH.PARA: That the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege be requested to consider, as part of its report on the law and practice of parliamentary privilege, such policy issues as arise from the matters raised by Senator Bolkus in the Senate on 4 October 1983 relating to certain statements made by counsel appearing before the Hope Royal Commission.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I express some satisfaction at the move made by Senator Bolkus to substitute this new motion for the one he moved in the Senate on 4 October 1983. On 4 October 1983, Senator Bolkus made another speech on the goings-on in the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies. He finished his speech by saying :

SPEECH.PARA: . . . I contend that the powers of parliamentary privilege vested in this Parliament under the Australian Constitution override whatever protection may be claimed by counsel under the Royal Commission Act, especially section 73 thereof .
The 'thereof' indicates that he is a lawyer, as he claims. That is a definite indication. He continued:
I claim that these statements of counsel constitute a breach of parliamentary privilege and, accordingly, I move:

That the comments of Mr Charles QC in the Royal Commission on Australia's Security and Intelligence Agencies and especially those comments referring to Senator Bolkus on page 5532 thereof be referred to the Senate Privileges Committee for consideration and report.

That seemed to be yet another inappropriate episode in a series of grossly inappropriate episodes which have been brought on us by everybody opposite, from the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) down. This is, of course, part of the saga in which the Prime Minister of Australia endeavoured to prevent the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) from daring to comment on matters relevant to the Royal Commission. All honourable senators should remember that the Prime Minister, the Honourable Bob, although he seems now to have gone to the Honourable R. J. Hawke , chose to threaten the Leader of the Opposition when he commented on the Royal Commission. Indeed, apparently he instructed counsel for the Commonwealth to raise the matter before the Royal Commission. It is common knowledge, because it was published, that Mr McHugh did raise this matter before the Royal Commission. The Leader of the Opposition publicly took the view at that time-I commend him for it-that he would not be prevented from commenting on matters of public interest by threats of the sort which were made by Mr Hawke.

The fact is that this is but one example of a government which seems very ready to preach openness and to talk about the virtues of open government and civil liberties and all the rest, and yet we had the extraordinary situation that the Leader of the Opposition in Australia was threatened by the Prime Minister because he dared to comment on a matter of public interest which was before the Commission. It is in that context that we see how extraordinary is this follow- up action by Senator Bolkus. Senator Bolkus proceeded to tell us about some of the things which had been said both by counsel instructed by his Government, Mr McHugh, and counsel instructed by the Australian Security Intelligence Organisation. He complained that there had been a breach of privilege and he sought to move for reference to a committee of which he, Senator Bolkus, is a member. This motion which is now before us is something of a step forward because Senator Bolkus is seeking to send to a committee not an allegation of a specific breach of privilege but such policy issues as arise from the matter raised by Senator Bolkus in the Senate on 4 October 1983 relating to certain statements made by counsel appearing before the Hope Royal Commission.

If one examines the terms of reference of the Committee to which Senator Bolkus is now seeking to have this referred, it is quite clear that this is a very considerable climb down by Senator Bolkus and, I might say on behalf of the Opposition, a very appropriate climb down. Of course, the behaviour that he was indulging in was not particularly helpful to the Government of which he is supposedly a supporter, with the great difficulties it has within its own ranks about the way it has handled this matter. The handing of this matter has been a travesty often of the sort of principles for which this Government is purported to stand. The Attorney-General (Senator Gareth Evans) sits there looking seedy, as well he might. Mr President, if you look at the reference to the Committee to which Senator Bolkus now wants to put these questions of policy, we find this statement:
(1) That a joint select committee be appointed to review, and report whether any changes are desirable in respect of-
(a) the law and practice of parliamentary privilege as they affect the Senate and the House of Representatives, and the Members and the committees of each House;
(b) the procedures by which cases of alleged breaches of parliamentary privilege may be raised, investigated and determined, and
(c) the penalties that may be imposed for breach of parliamentary privilege.

So we have a broad philosophic, academic and theoretical inquiry into these very important matters which go to the functioning of this Parliament. I believe that the inquiry is one which is warranted and I hope that the Joint Select Committee will produce a useful report for our guidance. I also hope that following the passage of this motion-I am sure it will be passed as it will be supported by the Opposition-some of the interesting questions which go to possible conflicts between the privilege of this place and the privileges which might be enjoyed by royal commissions and the possible restrictions on free speech which exist both outside this place, before royal commissions and in this place might also be examined. So I think some good may come out of what was a rather foolish expedition at the beginning and I hope that we will get something useful which might prevent some of the sudden sallies which we were treated to on 4 October and which I thought were puerile and certainly did nothing for the dignity of this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had understood that this motion in its revised form was to proceed to a vote without substantive debate in this place on the basis of its clear acceptance on all sides of this chamber. The Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney), as so often, has stretched the tolerance of members of the Government Party, and I would think any other objective observer at the moment, by the conspicuously offensive and tendentious character of the remarks that he has just made. I say only this: I have views of my own as to the particular matters that have been raised by Senator Bolkus and I have expressed them to Senator Bolkus on one or two occasions. It is entirely appropriate that the underlying policy issues that have been there and raised by Senator Bolkus be referred to the Joint Select Committee on Parliamentary Privilege. I would have thought it might be possible for the Senate to proceed to produce that result with rather more dignity than that with which it has just been treated by the Leader of the Opposition.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 2) corrects a number of anomalies and inconsistencies in sales tax law and makes certain structural changes that were announced by the Government at the time of the Budget. Some items are taken into a higher category, some other items are exempt, some items are to be taxable at lower rates and other previously exempt items become taxable. I make some observations with regard to some of the decisions that will result from the Bill , but I indicate on behalf of my colleagues that it will not be opposed. It ought to be said that the Bill does contradict some of the rhetoric that we heard when in government with regard to proposed changes that were introduced by us. I think it is of interest to see the changes in attitude that have resulted in the Government's measures on its accession to government.

SPEECH.PARA: Some of the matters that have been raised by a lot of concerned manufacturers and individuals may be raised by some of my colleagues, but I would like to point to one or two of them. Decisions have been made that will now result in air conditioning ducting, which was previously exempt from sales tax, being included in the tax schedules. This is of concern to a number of the building industries. It is one area to which the present Government, when in opposition, took exception when we introduced legislation with regard to building materials. I point out that at that time the building materials were to be introduced at a tax rate of 2 1/2 per cent but the air conditioning ducting referred to in this Bill is taxed at an effective rate of 20 per cent. I am advised that in a typical commercial building project air conditioning comprises about 10 per cent of building costs. Of this 10 per cent, 20 per cent is for ducting. So this effective tax on building materials is quite contradictory to the then Opposition's stance at the time that we were making some modest changes to a broader indirect tax base.

A number of representations have been made to me, and I am aware that these representations regarding air conditioning ducts and costs have been made to the Government. It is obvious that the Government does not respond in a positive way unless it intends to move amendments to legislation. I simply point out the fact that those who are involved in building have pointed to the increase in costs that will result from this new tax on the air conditioning materials.

I found some matters of interest in the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills concerning this sales tax legislation. It particularly drew attention to the provision of goods to be used by the profoundly deaf. This is a measure I certainly welcome-that consideration was given in the use of these materials to those who are profoundly deaf. But the Scrutiny of Bills Committee did draw attention to the discretion of the Commissioner of Taxation with regard to his capacity to determine the value of and the level at which it would be appropriate for this measure to be considered. People who work with the profoundly deaf have also drawn attention to the inadequacy of the definition, if it is to have the effect of giving relief to those who could benefit from it. As I understand it, the Government has also been made aware of these representations and I am not aware of any changes it wishes to make. But I do welcome the fact that there is some relief to the profoundly deaf in the use of these benefits. I think that some of the representations made to me were made quite seriously and with concern that perhaps an amendment to the definition may result in it being more widely able to be of benefit to a larger number of people.

I have had a lot of representations with regard to swimming pools, and again I am aware that the detail of these has been referred to the Government. The representations did result in some amendments being moved by the Government when the legislation was debated in the other place, but I am advised that there are still problems. There are now anomalies with regard to the treatment of materials used in the swimming pools. Proposals that have come through from the Australian Spa and Pool Associations Ltd are to the effect that a number of items should be restored to exemption and that changes should again be made to remove the anomalies that now exist. Again, I understand the Government has not found it possible to respond positively to the representations that have been made. Representations were made by cosmetic and toiletry manufacturers who have pointed to some of their difficulties. Other manufacturers have pointed to a whole range of difficulties, in particular some berry fruit industries in Tasmania and the effect of changes with regard to closer economic relations with New Zealand. As I have said, we have listened to all of these representations. We are aware that they have been made to the Government.

As this Bill introduces changes announced in the Budget which the Government desires to make to sales tax legislation, the Opposition does not oppose it. I hope that those representations which have been made seriously and conscientiously are considered by the Government, and that where anomalies still exist or have been created by the changes in this legislation, the Government will address those in its own time and that it may make some relief to those who are adversely affected by the proposed changes.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make one or two comments on the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Amendment Bill 1983 (No. 2). I recall that some time ago, when the Fraser Government was in charge of the country's economic welfare, I made some comments about the support that I would give to sales tax measures in order to broaden the taxation base in Australia. I pointed to a list showing that Australia, when compared with twenty-three other countries, raised the second lowest percentage of total revenue through sales tax. I pointed out at that time-on 8 September 1971-that Australia raised 6.8 per cent of its revenue through this source, whereas France raised 23.7 per cent and Austria 21.7 per cent of their revenue in this way. We raised the second to lowest amount of revenue through this source.

SPEECH.PARA: It is important that we examine this method of taxation with the object of reducing income tax, which is too high in Australia at present. On the previous occasion to which I referred I pointed to my concern about the way in which sales tax changes were introduced and the disruption and dislocation that this caused industries throughout Australia. I pointed also to my concern about the retroactive effect of these measures. At that time, I believe, a number of companies in Australia were disadvantaged because, having made financial or contractual arrangements well before the Budget date and having been assured that no sales tax applied to the various commodities that they were dealing with , they were faced after the August Budget with retroactive tax going back something like six months. The same, of course, applies with this legislation.

Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle mentioned particularly the Council of Australasian Spa and Pool Associations Limited. That body has made representations to me, as it has to a number of other senators. I think that the points it raises are quite pertinent to the debate and ought to be borne in mind by the Government on future occasions when it contemplates sales tax increases of this character. As far as the swimming pool associations are concerned, the legislation is discriminatory because it discriminates against various types of pools. I think that in itself is bad. I will elaborate on that later.

The Council of Australasian Spa and Pool Associations Ltd has indicated that it appreciates the Government's initiative and sympathy in its amendment of the sales tax measures affecting the industry. However, it has indicated two major areas of concern which will have an adverse effect on the industry and will cause serious dislocation. First, the measures still discriminate against and within two major market segments, albeit less severely than those previously announced, because some changes were effected. Secondly, the Council is concerned about the retrospective or retroactive effect of these amendments, particularly by taxing pre-Budget contracts. It indicated that this will cause disputes and cancellations to the detriment of the industry and the consuming public. It also pointed out that it viewed those issues so seriously that it wanted to pursue them in an effort to avoid potentially inequitable and burdensome features of the revised tax measures. The Council informed me that it has approximately 480 members Australia-wide and also represents the industry in New Zealand. Its members represent approximately 85 per cent of the swimming pool and spa industry's total sales and employ 10,000 people who rely directly on the pool and spa industry for their work.

The industry's total turnover is approximately $400m a year at retail prices and it uses a considerable amount of Australian-made products each year. It uses approximately 4,000 tonnes of galvanised sheet steel, approximately 10,000 tonnes of reinforcing steel, approximately 600 tonnes of plastic raw material for swimming pool filters only, approximately 200,000 cubic metres of concrete, approximately two million linear metres of vinyl, about 85,000 electric motors, approximately 1,200,000 kilograms of fibreglass, about 2.4 million kilograms of rosin and approximately 400,000 kilograms of gelcoat. The thing that interested me was that the Council made a very constructive proposal to the Treasurer and pointed out that if the sales tax were applied in an equitable way it would have no objection to it. OLSA, in its support of this request, says:

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that in addition the Government has not given adequate consideration, once more, to the transitional provisions that need to apply when a new sales tax is increased, particularly in this case. While sections 70A and 70B of the Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1) allow for agreements to be altered when the rate of sales tax is altered, these provisions refer only to the sale of goods and, therefore, are not adequate to deal with fixed price lump sum fabrication supply and installation contracts. In these instances the labour costs, as well as the materials, need to be included when considerating contracts entered into before the change in the sales tax. I have made representations to the Acting Treasurer on this matter. I received a fairly lengthy response from him. I prefer not to take up the time of the Committee in reading that response. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard part of the response from the Acting Treasurer.
Leave granted.
The response read as follows-

I have looked into this matter and I am advised by the Commissioner of Taxation that in his view the law adequately provides for the passing on of the sales tax increases in all cases. The relevant sections of the law are sections 70A and 70B of Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1). You are, of course, aware of the operation of section 70A which relates to the passing on of sales tax increases in the case of sales of goods but your concern was with section 70B.

Here the Commissioner said that in his view it is appropriate to regard the expression ''the material'' in section 70B as the duct work because it is the duct work that is being supplied for use in connexion with the contract by the air conditioning contractor. This being the case, section 70B would allow for the passing on of sales tax payable by the contractor in respect of the duct work. On a further view, it is arguable that section 70B applies to all the material supplied under the contract which becomes the property of the other contracting party i.e. sheet metal, nuts, bolts, etc. and because the duct work is part of the material so supplied, the contractor may pass on the sales tax increase attributable to it.

The Commissioner added that there is also another possible remedy for the contractor under the law. There is a provision, section 3 (4) of Sales Tax Assessment Act (No. 1), which deems a sale of goods to take place where, in a work and labour contract like the contracts currently under consideration, a person (contractor) supplies goods the property in which passes under the contract to some other person. The Commissioner said that there is no doubt that property in the duct work passes under the terms of the contract to the other party. This being the case, section 3 (4) deems there to be a sale of goods, namely, the duct work, which then brings section 70A into play and would allow the contractor to pass on the sales tax increase.

The Commissioner also said that sections 70A and 70B were inserted in the law expressly to give certain rights to contractors to allow them to pass on tax increases that occur after they have contracted to supply goods. Those sections are for the benefit of the contractors and it is not a matter in which he considers that he should intervene. The Commissioner is of the view that the law as expressed provides for the tax to be passed on and whether a contractor wishes to avail himself of this is a matter between himself and the other contracting party.

I might add that I am in agreement with this view. It seems to me that the appropriate course to take in this situation is to let, in the first place, the contractors sort out the matter between themselves.

If it transpires that, contrary to the Commissioner's view, section 70A and 70B do not allow for the tax to be passed on, then the Government will give consideration to remedying the situation. However, I think that no action is called for on the part of the Government until such time as the law is shown to be defective.

TALK.START.PARA: —The problem is that because of this increase there will be a reduced demand. The Conference passed a motion (Page 113) that recommended control of the satellite should be vested in AUSSAT and that body should continue as a relatively, small independent and effective organisation.

The Conference felt it would be unacceptable for the project to be channelled into the Telecom network. In the past Telecom had shown no desire or capacity to operate the satellite system, in fact in 1970 when the proposal was first put to them they rejected it. As you are aware this led to private sponsorship of the project and the recommendation of a Government task force that the satellite project should proceed independent of Telecom.
The fact that the satellite system is so close to introduction is despite Telecom's indifference and due solely to private enterprise sponsorship.

A further motion passed at the Conference called on the Government for the allocation of necessary financial and physical resources from modern telephone, television and radio services to Australians in remote areas as quickly as possible.

On reading the proceedings of the Conference you will understand the critical need for effective communications in the vast area of Australia; an area of immense growth and vitality which even now plays a key part in Australia's export earnings as well as an area which is the gateway to Asia and all the possibilities of trade open to us there.

Also enclosed are letters from the Gulf Local Authorities Development Committee addressed to the Prime Minister and yourself. The Council asked that these be handed to you when the delegation met with you.

The message from the Conference in Alice Springs is that the satellite project is vital to the further advancement of Northern Australia and that effective telecommunications are the right of every Australian, not just those living in the heavily populated areas of the nation.
Your sincerely,
IAN TUXWORTH.

TALK.START.PARA: —As Question Time is most competitive these days and at times it takes a while for an opportunity to come around to each senator, I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Communications the following question with reference to a report sent to the Minister for Communications regarding the proceedings of the Aussat Conference held in Alice Springs on Saturday 16 July: First, when will a decision be made on the operations of the Aussat satellite; secondly, does the Minister accept the report of the conference, and in particular the recommendations that control of the satellite be vested in Aussat and that the Aussat body continue as a relatively small, independent and effective organisation; thirdly, what plans does the Government have for the allocation of the necessary financial and physical resources to ensure that Australians in remote areas receive modern telephone, television and radio services as quickly as possible? This is an extremely important subject, particularly to the people of the outback and remote areas. I seek that information from the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: The second question that I ask the Government relates to the Skyhawk fighter aircraft. Is the report correct that the Royal Australian Navy surplus Skyhawk fighters that were previously based on the aircraft carrier, Melbourne, were offered to the Royal New Zealand Air Force but were rejected as the price was considered too high? Having in mind the close association of New Zealand in defence, right back to the days of ANZAC, when the New Zealanders were complete comrades, and the fact that Australia and New Zealand are both signatories to the ANZUS Treaty, will the Australian Government offer the Skyhawks to the New Zealand Government at an acceptable price so that they become part of this region's defence? It is most unfortunate that because we no longer have an aircraft carrier the Skyhawk fighters are surplus. They could be sent to any part of the world, wherever there is a buyer prepared to pay the right price. I believe that such fighters should be retained in this area. The price should be such that it is attractive to New Zealand, so that they can enter the Royal New Zealand Air Force and become part of the defence of this region.

Lastly, I refer to the tussle that is taking place regarding the chairmanship of the Northern Land Council in the Northern Territory. It was indicated in the Northern Territory News yesterday that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Clyde Holding, has appointed an interim chairman to the Northern Land Council, a Mr Silas Maralugurra. The Chairman who has been replaced is Mr Gerry Blitner. On 7 October he sent a telegram to Mr Clyde Holding, saying:

By letter of 23 August 1983, you extended the term of the Land Council and I claim that I am still the Chairman of the Northern Land Council on the basis that the Minister, under the provisions of the Act, extended the term of the Council including my own term. As such, the chairmanship was not declared vacant , and I ask you to immediately confirm that I am, under the Act, the legal Chairman of the Northern Land Council until midnight on 12 October 1983.

I expect another election to take place then. I seek the Federal Government's advice as to why this action has been taken. First, as the Minister has claimed that he has the power to extend the term of the Northern Land Council, which he has done, he has appointed an interim chairman; but at the same time he says that he has no legal power to extend the chairmanship of the Northern Land Council. Of course, the Chairman is Mr Gerry Blitner. This matter has left a bad taste in the Northern Territory. It is unfortunate that there should be this wrangle over the chairmanship of the Northern Land Council. It is unfortunate because, as there is to be an election for the chairmanship of the Northern Land Council, Mr Gerry Blitner could have remained in the chair. But the Minister says that he has no legal power, although apparently he has legal power to do other things. I ask the Government for a report on this matter indicating why this action has been taken. Was it really so necessary to remove Mr Gerry Blitner from office?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff has raised three matters. On the basis of the information available to me, I shall do my best to answer at least two of them. As to the Aussat matter, the Minister for Communications (Mr Duffy) has supplied me with notes as follows: The planning of the satellite and the decisions relating to it are following a countdown leading to the scheduled launch date in late 1985, and planning is on schedule against that time-table. The Government recognises the need for control of the satellite to be effective and responsive to needs, as it does for the whole communications system. With regard to the actual form of organisation there is a need, in the national interest and to ensure the greatest economy, to ensure that its use is properly co-ordinated with the existing system.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is aware that there are a number of ways in which this might be done, and they are being closely examined. One of the purposes of the satellite and other programs, such as the remote or underserviced communities scheme in radio and television, is to eliminate the penalties with respect to communications which arise from remoteness and are well understood and, of course, acknowledged by the Government. The Government is actively supporting all of these programs and others such as School of the Air services as much as resources permit. To the extent that Senator Kilgariff has raised other questions that are not answered by that general statement, I will draw his remarks to the attention of the Minister and seek such early reply as may be appropriate.

As to the second question, concerning the possible sale of surplus Skyhawk aircraft to the Royal New Zealand Air Force, I am afraid I have no information on that presently to hand. I will refer Senator Kilgariff's expressions of concern to the Minister for Defence (Mr Scholes) and seek an early reply.

As to the question of the chairmanship of the Northern Land Council, I do have a fairly detailed note from the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Holding) which, if the Senate will bear with me, I will do my best now to explain for the record. It is the case that Mr Blitner is no longer Chairman of the NLC. His term of office expired on 29 August 1983. The Aboriginal Land Rights Act provides that the Chairman shall hold office for three years but makes no provision for the extension of that term in any way. Under normal circumstances, the election of the NLC would have occurred prior to 29 August 1983 but the life of the present Council was extended-pursuant to provisions which do exist in the Act, unlike in relation to the chairmanship-to facilitate the expansion of membership for the Council.

The particular circumstances, I am told, leading to the conclusion of Mr Blitner's term of office prior to the election of a new Council are as follows: On 12 August Mr Blitner and the Minister discussed the desirability of expanding the membership of the NLC so that greater representation could be given to Aboriginals in a number of communities throughout the Top End of the Northern Territory, particularly those residing on pastoral properties. In order to allow the necessary communications to be made and nominations to be received, the Minister agreed to extend the life of the present Council in order that this work could be carried out.

On 19 August the Minister received a formal request from Mr Blitner to extend the life of the present Council to midnight on 26 September. He approved the request in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Aboriginal Land Rights Act.

On 21 September the Minister received a further request from the Acting General Manager, Mr Tietzel, to further extend the life of the existing Council to midnight on 12 October. This was to allow additional time for those communities who had yet to nominate members to respond and also to ensure that all members could travel to Darwin for the proposed elections. The Minister approved that request.

Whilst the legislation, as I have indicated, allows for the Minister extending the life of a council, it does not provide any authority for the Minister to extend the term of office of the Chairman beyond the three years set down in the legislation. Consequently, as a result of the Minister extending the life of the Council as requested, the three year period during which Mr Blitner held office as Chairman did expire.

The situation as it now stands is that a new Council with expanded membership will meet on 13 October-in a couple of days time-and elect a Chairman, Deputy Chairman and executive officers. The Minister says that while he regrets any misunderstanding that may have resulted as a consequence of extending the life of the Council, particularly in relation to the legal implications of such an extension, he is confident that all actions have been taken in good faith and within the law. He also remains confident that the new Council will be more representative of the Aboriginal people in the Top End of the Northern Territory .

I believe that does at least clarify the basis for the Minister's actions in this respect. I will ensure that Senator Kilgariff's remarks are drawn to the Minister's attention. If there is any other aspect of Senator Kilgariff's remarks on which the Minister cares to add some further comment, I will ensure that that reply is forthcoming.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 April 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What are the national and State by State figures on foreclosure of mortgages by banks, building societies and financial institutions for the years 1978-79 to 1981-82.

(2) Did the former Government use such figures to establish the level of tax rebate on home loan repayments announced in the Budget; if not, what statistical base was used to calculate the level of rebate.
(3) Can the Government be sure that the system is not open to abuse as an avenue for avoiding tax if there was no statistical base.
(4) Does the Government intend to monitor the operation of the rebate scheme in light of suggestions that it may be open to tax avoidance.
(5) Would the Government tighten up the conditions under which people are eligible for the rebate if there was evidence of tax avoidance.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Foreclosure is a legal process involving the transfer of title to a mortgagee and is rarely invoked in Australia. The general means of enforcing a mortgage security is for the mortgagee to sell as mortgagee-in-possession. The essential difference is that under the second approach any surplus funds are returned to the mortgagor and not retained by the mortgagee. Official statistics on foreclosures or sales by mortgagees-in-possession are not available.

Against that background, I am advised that official comprehensive statistics on housing loan foreclosures for the period 1978-79 to 1981-82 are not available. This is due to a number of factors, not the least of which is the wide and varied number of financial institutions which lend for housing. In addition, not all of these institutions fall under Commonwealth Government legislation. For example, non-bank financial institutions, including building societies, fall under the authority of State Governments, while State banking, apart from that part of it extending beyond the limits of the State concerned, is constitutionally a matter of State responsibility.

(2) For reasons of Cabinet government proprieties which the honourable senator will understand, I do not have access to any advice on the matter which may have formed part of the deliberative processes of the previous Government.

(3) and (4) The Commissioner of Taxation has advised that, as with many other claims that taxpayers make, his Office will rely primarily on voluntary compliance by taxpayers in making their claims for home loan interest rebates. It can be expected however that, in the light of the information to be provided in return forms, a reasonable percentage of taxpayers will be asked to supply evidence in support of the details on which their claims are based. The guidance notes being issued for taxpayer use in connection with the rebates indicate that the Taxation Office may ask for evidence to be supplied. A claim could also be checked during the course of normal investigation and audit activities.
The Commissioner has also pointed out that the law provides severe penalties for taxpayers who make a return which is false in any particular.

(5) If the circumstances were thought to warrant it, the Government would give serious consideration to measures designed to prevent tax avoidance through the rebate arrangements in line with its announced policy of giving high priority to combating tax avoidance and evasion.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 20 September 1983:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the purpose of the spouse carer's pension.
(2) What pensions or benefits will it replace.
(3) How many people (men) will be eligible, and from which benefits/pensions will they become ineligible.
(4) What measures will be undertaken to make potential recipients aware of the availability of this pension.
(5) What will be the estimated take-up rate of this pension and what is the full year cost.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen The Hon D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) To provide income support for men providing constant care and attention for their severely handicapped age or invalid pensioner wives at home.

(2) The spouse carer's pension will be a completely new form of assistance. However it is expected that most men who currently receive special benefit because they are required to provide long-term care for an invalid wife will transfer to the pension.

(3) It is not possible to estimate accurately the likely number of recipients of the new pension or its cost. A best guess is that some 2,000 men may be eligible for the spouse carer's pension at a cost of some $2.3m in the current financial year and $5.0m in a full year. Recipients of the pension will be ineligible to receive simultaneously an age or invalid pension, unemployment, sickness or special benefit or a service pension.
(4) My Department is currently examining special measures to make the spouse carer's pension more widely known to potential recipients.

(5) No accurate estimate of take-up can be made. It is not known how many pensioner wives are in need of constant care and attention, nor how many eligible husbands, now in the labour force, will be encouraged to provide such care. See also (3) above.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 May 1983 (Hansard, page 699), Senator Cook asked the following question, without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Has the Attorney-General seen an article headed 'Court finds Tubemakers guilty of WA steel ''fix'' ', which appeared in yesterday's Australian Financial Review ? Did the article report that companies associated with the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, namely, Steel Supplies (Aust) Pty Ltd and Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, and a Steel Supplies director, Mr Barry Neil Bint, have been convicted by Mr Justice Toohey under section 45 of the Trade Practices Act of ' illegally attempting to control steel prices in Western Australia'? Is the Minister able to say how much these price fixing activities have cost consumers in Western Australia? Will the Government consider amending trade practices law to enable injured consumers to take a class action against offenders of this type?
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:
In answering Senator Cook, I said if I could get further information about how much the price fixing activities in question may have cost consumers, I would advise the honourable senator accordingly.

On 26 August 1983, Toohey J. fined the respondents a total of $27,000 plus costs in respect of the attempted breaches of the Trade Practices Act. He stated that no loss or damage had been suffered in the case except by the respondents themselves. He also stated that, had the steel merchants arrived at an arrangement or understanding to control discounts, there would have been a serious infringement of section 45 of the Trade Practices Act and one with serious commercial consequences.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 May 1983 (Hansard, page 899), Senator Messner asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, a question without notice concerning whether the new tax arrangements to apply to lump sum superannuation and kindred payments would apply to such payments at death.

ANSWER.PARA: The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Following representations and submissions to the Government on the scope of the new lump sum tax measures, it has been decided to exclude from their ambit lump sums paid by a superannuation fund or employer to the estate, widow, widower or dependants of a deceased fund member or employee. Such payments will therefore continue to be exempt from tax in the recipient's hands. It was never proposed to include within the new lump sum tax arrangements non-superannuation life policies purchased by individuals.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 September 1983 (Hansard, page 762), Senator Lajovic asked me, as Minister representing the Treasurer, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: Can the Minister obtain for the Senate the following information regarding the composition of the consumer price index basket: Firstly, what is the present composition of the basket? Secondly, who decides, and on what basis, the actual composition of the basket? Finally, is there any intention to change the present composition in the near future?
The Treasurer has provided the following supplementary information in answer to the honourable senator's question:
The Australian Statistician is responsible for producing the consumer price index-CPI-and for determining its composition and method of construction.

In July 1982, at the time when the tenth series of the CPI was introduced, the Australian Statistician published an information paper 'Review of the Consumer Price Index'-Catalogue No. 6450.0-which covers the questions asked by the honourable senator. That paper describes how the review was undertaken and includes details of the areas of expenditure included in the index, the relative weighting assigned to each in compiling the index, and information on the goods and services for which prices are collected. Copies of this paper are available in the Parliamentary Library and I am making separate arrangements for a copy to be sent to the honourable senator.
The Statistician advises that there are no plans to change the composition of the CPI in the near future as the last major review has only recently been completed.
